video.title: Story of Seasons: Pioneers of Olive Town (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text:
So after I reviewed Harvest Moon One Star
a few weeks back and said it was the imperfect

pod person replica of the original franchise
that got rejected for forgetting to glue its

nose on properly, and that you should probably
hold out for the new Story of Seasons, I immediately

realised, oh crunchy nut bugger flakes, I&#39;ve
tied my hands on this one, haven&#39;t I. I basically

endorsed Story of Seasons: Pioneers of Olive
Town sight unseen so now I have to review

it to make sure it doesn&#39;t leave skidmarks
on the guest towels. After all, it&#39;s not like

the original Harvest Moon developers are hoarding
the secret formula for light farming sims

like it&#39;s the recipe for Coke- you just need
a twenty minute day cycle, a brace of anime

hotties and an at best truncated idea of childbirth.
Some of the original Harvest Moons were stinkers,

like that one on the Gamecube from the &quot;make
everything look like we&#39;re viewing it through

a coffee filter&quot; era of graphics that had
all the visual charm of the top layer of scum

on the pond behind the abattoir. If you want
to know if Pioneers of Olive Drab is better

than Harvest Moon One Wank then yes it is,
but that&#39;s not much of a bar to clear.

Nice job guys, you completed a one page assignment
without resorting to twenty-four point text

and triple spacing. The question is if it
lives up to the current standard for light

farming sims, which to my mind is Stardew
Valley. Which I hear just got another free

content update, because the developer&#39;s doing
it out of love and is apparently allergic

to money or something. And if there&#39;s one
thing that condemns Story of Seasons before

it&#39;s even wobbled out of the fuck shed on
bloodstained newborn legs, it&#39;s that it hasn&#39;t

done a whole lot of updating over the years.
At least Wonky World was trying something

new. It went for the kickflip and broke its
nose on its own selfie stick but Story of

Seasons isn&#39;t even in the skate park, it&#39;s
at home assembling the same jigsaw puzzle

as always - growing, harvesting, fishing,
mining, chickens first then cows and all the

animals look like overinflated balloons and
think &quot;foot and mouth disease&quot; is just a euphemism

for saying the wrong thing at a social gathering.
It&#39;s only really improved graphically over

the years, and call me a pointlessly persistent
proponent of pixel art but I feel that top

down cartoon farming is a concept that just
doesn&#39;t benefit from full 3D.

I mean, I go around town for the first day&#39;s
waifu hunt and all I have to go on are a bunch

of tottering dead-eyed Bratz doll mascots
that cause nary a stir in my character&#39;s humble

flaxen underpants and they don&#39;t even have
attractive 2D portraits of the characters

to throw on top of their dialogue boxes so
you can get a feel for how they&#39;d look once

you&#39;ve got a serious set of beer goggles on.
In the end I zeroed in on the one lady who

appraises relics you find in the mine, just
because I was seeing her every day anyway

when I dropped off that day&#39;s sackload of
earth-caked garbage. It&#39;s hard to feel electrified

with romance settling for the girl I would
have no reason to interact with were I to

just buy my own fucking pressure washer. On
that note, if you want to hear about new features,

Story of Seasons has pinched a few eggs from
Animal Crossing&#39;s Easter basket, in that you

can donate fish and relics to the museum,
so every time you find a new fish you react

not with joy but with eye-rolling dismay at
now having to let it stink up your inventory

until you can get to the museum again. And
then having to pick where to display the fucking

thing like I had time to learn how to curate
a fucking aquarium while I was learning how
to milk a spherical cow.

There&#39;s also some Animal Crossing-y online
features where you can visit other people&#39;s

farms and marvel at how their turnip patch
is a slightly different shape than yours.

Who&#39;s got time for that shit? I have to moisten
all my crops then head out waifu hunting and

moisten some other things. But who the fuck&#39;s
demanding innovation from their light farming

sims? As I say the formula&#39;s pretty much down
so it&#39;s like trying to liven up a perfectly

good money shot by using spicy mustard instead
of cum. Let me just say this now: if you&#39;ve

never played a light farming sim and don&#39;t
want to try Stardew Valley because Eric Barone

murdered your family or something then you&#39;ll
get the full light farming experience with

Pioneers of Bollock City. All I can do at
this point is nitpick the little ways I don&#39;t

like it as much as others. So I&#39;ve gone over
the waifus - just the way they like it, am

I right, fellas - I also don&#39;t like the loading
times. And they&#39;re not helped by the loading

screens all being what I think must be photos
taken by other players, because they&#39;re usually

blurry and poorly cropped images of somebody&#39;s
armpit. I also have a specific bubble in my
catheter tube about coal.

You need coal to power certain machines, but
I tried to stick some coal I found in the

mine into one and it slapped my hand away.
&quot;No! I only want REFINED coal!&quot; So a little

searching around later I discovered a crafting
recipe that I&#39;d picked up without realising

that turned one piece of raw coal into one
piece of refined coal. If you needed more

than one raw coal to make refined coal or
if there were other things you could do with

raw coal besides make refined coal then this
would be a gameplay mechanic. As it stands,

it&#39;s just pissing about. Right, what else.
I do like how you make lumber machines out

of basic wood. Because it means when you get
your wood Bachelor&#39;s degree and graduate to

advanced wood you still have a use for all
the basic wood that&#39;s still lying around.

Trouble is, you don&#39;t need to get far along
the tech tree before the game starts demanding

large quantities of lumber and when a lumber
machine can only make one at a time and the

lumber machines are practicing social distancing
so you can&#39;t cram them up next to each other

you end up with rolling meadows of fucking
lumber machines and that&#39;s not the kind of

scenery I hoped to spend my retirement gazing
out at from the farmhouse window.

My gut tells me this game is simultaneously
a bit too slow and a bit too fast. Does your

gut wanna clarify that, Yahtz? Well, I don&#39;t
want to push him, we had Mexican last night.

The days might be a touch too long because
I kept running out of things to do, but at

the same time, stuff seems to respawn a bit
too fast. I guess we need the trees since

we go through lumber like a termite colony
under an IKEA warehouse but as my farm expands

I feel like I&#39;m spending half the morning
holding the weeds back. Also, I feel like

development happens too fast early on, and
not because I&#39;m working hard. I&#39;d upgraded

to both iron tools and silver tools before
I was halfway through the first Spring, and

I didn&#39;t even have to pay for a chicken coop,
there was one already there. Complete with

one free wild chicken that was leaning against
the wall ready to go tame for the first passing

farmer to pat it on the head, and it&#39;s only
their blind luck that I didn&#39;t happen to be

setting up a teriyaki restaurant. See, you&#39;re
more emotionally attached to something you&#39;ve

had to wait for and put a bit of work into,
I suppose. That&#39;s why I&#39;ve started putting
on oven mitts to jerk off.
